briefTitle: A Study of the Effectiveness and Safety of Sustained-release Hydromorphone (a Strong Opioid) in Patients With Chronic Noncancer Pain.

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* Adult patients with chronic noncancer pain severe enough to require continuous opioid therapy (a score of at least 5 in "pain right now" on a 11 point numeric rating scale) who have never received an opioid or are currently treated with a weak opioid, and who experience insufficient pain control.

Exclusion Criteria:

* Patients who have been treated with strong opioids (including hydromorphone and oxycodone) within the last 4 weeks prior to study inclusion or who will probably undergo any treatment (e.g. neurological techniques, surgery) within the next 6 months, which may abruptly alter degree or nature of pain experienced
* patients with a history of disease(s), current illness, or therapy which would preclude them from participation in the study
* and patients who are pregnant or nursing.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline in Brief Pain Inventory (BPI) Questionnaire Item 6 "Pain Right Now" Score at Week 24 (Per Protocol [PP] Population)
outcomeMeasures.description: Assessment of non-inferiority of OROS hydromorphone compared with sustained release (SR) oxycodone with regard to pain control by measuring the change from baseline in pain severity, using BPI item 6 "pain right now" score at week 24. Scores could have ranged from 0 to 10, where 0 = no pain and 10 = pain as bad as you can imagine. Negative change from baseline scores indicate improvement in "pain right now".

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline in BPI Pain Severity Sub-score "Pain at Its Worst" (BPI Item 3) at Week 24 (ITT Population)
outcomeMeasures.description: Change from baseline to week 24 in BPI pain severity, pain at its worst (BPI item 3) assessed using the BPI questionnaire. Score values ranges from 0 (no pain) to 10 (pain as bad as you can imagine). Scores could have ranged from 0 to 10, where 0 = no pain and 10 = pain as bad as you can imagine. Negative change from baseline scores indicate improvement in "pain at its worst".

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline in BPI Questionnaire Item 6 "Pain Right Now" Score at Week 24 (Intent to Treat [ITT] Population)
outcomeMeasures.description: Assessment of non-inferiority of OROS hydromorphone compared with SR oxycodone with regard to pain control by measuring the change from baseline in pain severity, using BPI item 6 "pain right now" score at week 24. Scores could have ranged from 0 to 10, where 0 = no pain and 10 = pain as bad as you can imagine. Negative change from baseline scores indicate improvement in "pain right now".

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline in Sleep Quality at Week 24
outcomeMeasures.description: Change from baseline in sleep quality was assessed using the Medical Outcomes Study (MOS) questionnaire at week 24, specifically the sleep subscale index I. Score range 0 to 100, where 0 = best sleep quality and 100 = worst sleep quality. Negative change from baseline scores indicate improved sleep quality.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline in Subject Diary Evening Mean Pain Score "Pain Right Now" at Week 24
outcomeMeasures.description: Change from baseline to week 24 in subject diary evening mean pain score "pain right now". Subjects rated the severity of "pain right now" on a 10 point numeric scale, with 0 being the least pain and 10 being the most pain. Negative change from baseline scores indicate improvement in subject diary evening mean pain score "pain right now".

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline in Subject Diary Morning Mean Pain Score "Pain Right Now" at Week 24
outcomeMeasures.description: Change from baseline to week 24 in subject diary morning mean pain score "pain right now". Subjects rated the severity of "pain right now" on a 10 point numeric scale, with 0 being the least pain and 10 being the most pain. Negative change from baseline scores indicate improvement in subject diary evening mean pain score "pain right now".

outcomeMeasures.title: Number of Subjects With Dose Escalation
outcomeMeasures.description: Number of subjects with dose increase in study medication.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline in BPI Severity Score "Pain Right Now" (BPI Item 6) at Week 4
outcomeMeasures.description: Change from baseline in pain severity was assessed using the BPI questionnaire, specifically "pain right now" (BPI item 6) at week 4. Scores could have ranged from 0 to 10, where 0 = no pain and 10 = pain as bad as you can imagine. Negative change from baseline scores indicate improvement in "pain right now".

Scores could have ranged from 0 to 10, where 0 = no pain and 10 = pain as bad as you can imagine. Negative change from baseline scores indicate improvement in "pain at its least".

outcomeMeasures.description: Change from baseline in pain severity was assessed using the BPI questionnaire, specifically "pain at its worst" (BPI item 3) at week 4. outcomeMeasures.description: Change from baseline in pain severity was assessed using the BPI questionnaire, specifically "average pain" (BPI item 5) at week 4. outcomeMeasures.description: Change from baseline in pain severity was assessed using the BPI questionnaire, specifically pain relief (BPI item 8) at week 4. Scores could have ranged from 0 to 10, where 0 = no pain and 10 = pain as bad as you can imagine. Negative scores indicate improvement in pain severity.

Negative change from baseline scores indicate improvement in "pain interfered with enjoyment of life".

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline in BPI Pain Severity, Relief and Interference Scores (Extension Phase)
outcomeMeasures.description: Change from baseline in pain severity, pain relief, and pain interference was assessed using the BPI questionnaire at week 52. BPI items 3 to 6, score range 0 to 10, where 0 = no pain and 10 = pain as bad as you can imagine; BPI items 9a to 9g, score range from 0 to 10, where 0 = does not interfere and 10 = completely interferes. Negative change from baseline scores indicate improvement in pain severity and pain interference. BPI item 8, score range from 0 to 100, where 0 = no relief and 100 = complete relief. Positive change from baseline scores indicate improvement in pain relief.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline in Sleep Quality (MOS Index I) at Week 4
outcomeMeasures.description: Change from baseline in sleep quality was assessed using the sleep subscales of the MOS questionnaire, which consists of 12 items; MOS sleep scale index I (average of item 1, 3, 7, 8, 9, and 12) was assessed at week 4. Score range 0 to 100, where 0 = best sleep quality and 100 = worst sleep quality. Negative change from baseline scores indicate improvement in sleep quality.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline in Sleep Quality (MOS Index II) at Week 4
outcomeMeasures.description: Change from baseline in sleep quality was assessed using the sleep subscales of the MOS questionnaire, which consists of 12 items. MOS index II (average of items 1, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, and 12) was assessed at week 4. Score range 0 to 100, where 0 = best sleep quality and 100 = worst sleep quality. Negative change from baseline scores indicate improvement in sleep quality.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline in Sleep Quality (MOS Index II) at Week 24
outcomeMeasures.description: Change from baseline in sleep quality was assessed using the sleep subscales of the MOS questionnaire, which consists of 12 items. MOS index II (average of items 1, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, and 12) was assessed at week 24. Score range 0 to 100, where 0 = best sleep quality and 100 = worst sleep quality. Negative change from baseline scores indicate improvement in sleep quality.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline in Sleep Quality, Sleep Disturbance at Week 24
outcomeMeasures.description: Change from baseline in sleep quality (sleep disturbance) was assessed using the MOS questionnaire at week 24. Score range 0 to 100, where 0 = best sleep quality and 100 = worst sleep quality. Negative change from baseline scores indicate improvement in sleep disturbance.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline in Sleep Quality, Snoring at Week 24
outcomeMeasures.description: Change from baseline in sleep quality (snoring) was assessed using the MOS questionnaire at week 24. Score range 0 to 100, where 0 = best sleep quality and 100 = worst sleep quality. Negative change from baseline scores indicate improvement in snoring.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline in Sleep Quality, Sleep Shortness of Breath or Headache at Week 24
outcomeMeasures.description: Change from baseline in sleep quality (sleep shortness of breath or headache) was assessed using the MOS questionnaire at week 24. Score range 0 to 100, where 0 = best sleep quality and 100 = worst sleep quality. Negative change from baseline scores indicate improvement in sleep shortness of breath or headache.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline in Sleep Quality, Sleep Adequacy at Week 24
outcomeMeasures.description: Change from baseline in sleep quality (sleep adequacy) was assessed using the MOS questionnaire at week 24. Score range 0 to 100, where 0 = worst sleep quality and 100 = best sleep quality. Positive change from baseline scores indicate improvement in sleep adequacy.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline in Sleep Quality, Sleep Somnolence at Week 24
outcomeMeasures.description: Change from baseline in sleep quality (sleep somnolence) was assessed using the MOS questionnaire at week 24. Score range 0 to 100, where 0 = best sleep quality and 100 = worst sleep quality. Negative change from baseline scores indicate improvement in sleep somnolence.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline in Sleep Quality, Sleep Quantity at Week 24
outcomeMeasures.description: Change from baseline in sleep quality (sleep quantity) was assessed using the MOS questionnaire at week 24. Score range 0 to 100, where 0 = worst sleep quality and 100 = best sleep quality. Positive change from baseline scores indicate improvement in sleep quantity.

outcomeMeasures.title: Number of Subjects Indicating That They Had Optimal Sleep at Week 24
outcomeMeasures.description: Number of subjects indicating that they had optimal sleep was assessed based on the number of hours of sleep reported on the MOS questionnaire at week 24. Optimal sleep was defined as 7 to 8 hours sleep per night.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline in Sleep Quality at Week 52
outcomeMeasures.description: Change from baseline in sleep quality was assessed using the MOS questionnaire at week 52. Score range 0 to 100. For disturbance, snoring, shortness of breath or headache, and somnolence, 0 = best sleep quality and 100 = worst sleep quality; negative change from baseline scores indicate improvement in sleep quality for these measures. For adequacy and quantity, 0 = worst sleep quality and 100 = best sleep quality; positive change from baseline scores indicate improvement in sleep quality for these measures.

outcomeMeasures.title: Number of Subjects Indicating Optimal Sleep at Week 52
outcomeMeasures.description: Number of subjects who experienced optimal sleep was assessed based on the number of hours of sleep reported on the MOS questionnaire at week 52. Optimal sleep was defined as 7-8 hours sleep per night.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline in Subject Diary Mean Pain Evening, Morning, and All Day Scores at Week 24
outcomeMeasures.description: Change from baseline to week 24 in subject diary evening, morning and all day mean pain scores for pain right now, at its worst, at its least, and average. Subjects rated the severity of pain on a 10 point numeric scale, with 0 being the least pain and 10 being the most pain. Negative change from baseline scores indicate improvement in subject diary mean pain scores.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline in Subject Diary Mean Pain Score for "Pain at Its Worst" From Morning to Evening at Weeks 4, 8, 12, 16, 20, and 24
outcomeMeasures.description: Change from baseline in subject diary mean pain score "pain at its worst" from morning to evening at weeks 4, 8, 12, 16, 20, and 24. Subjects rated the severity of "pain right now" on a 10 point numeric scale, with 0 being the least pain and 10 being the most pain. Negative change from baseline scores indicate improvement in subject diary mean pain score "pain at its worst".

outcomeMeasures.title: Number of Subjects With Dose Escalation at Week 4 (ITT Population)
outcomeMeasures.description: The number of subjects with dose increase in study medication was assessed at week 4.

outcomeMeasures.title: Number of Subjects With Dose Escalation at Week 24 (ITT Population)
outcomeMeasures.description: The number of subjects with dose increase in study medication was assessed at week 24.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline in Quality of Life (QoL) "Bodily Pain" at Week 4
outcomeMeasures.description: Change from baseline in QoL was assessed using the Short Form (SF)-36 QoL questionnaire, specifically the SF-36 bodily pain index. Scores could range from 0 to 100, with a high score indicating a better QoL. Positive change from baseline scores indicate improvement in bodily pain.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline in QoL "General Health Perceptions" at Week 4

outcomeMeasures.description: Change from baseline in QoL was assessed using the SF-36 QoL questionnaire, specifically SF-36 bodily pain index score at week 24. Score could range from 0 to 100, with a high score indicating a better QoL. Positive change from baseline scores indicate improvement in bodily pain.

Scores could range from 0 to 100 with a higher score indicating a better QoL. Positive change from baseline scores indicate improvement in health perceptions.

outcomeMeasures.description: Change from baseline in QoL was assessed using the SF-36 QoL questionnaire, specifically SF-36 health transition score at week 24. Scores could range from 0 to 100, with a high score indicating a better QoL. Positive change from baseline score indicates improvement in mental health.

Scores could range from 0 to 100, with a high score indicating a better QoL. Positive change from baseline scores indicate improvement in physical functioning.

outcomeMeasures.description: Change from baseline in QoL was assessed using the SF-36 QoL questionnaire, specifically SF-36 role physical score at week 24. Scores could range from 0 to 100 with a high score indicating a better QoL. Positive change from baseline scores indicate improvement in role physical.

outcomeMeasures.description: Change from baseline in QoL was assessed using the SF-36 QoL questionnaire, specifically SF-36 social functioning score at week 24. Scores could range from 0 to 100 with a high score indicating a better QoL. Positive change from baseline scores indicate improvement in social functioning.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline in QoL "Vitality" at Week 24
outcomeMeasures.description: Change from baseline in QoL was assessed using the SF-36 QoL questionnaire, specifically SF-36 vitality score at week 24. Scores could range from 0 to 100 with a high score indicating a better QoL. Positive change from baseline scores indicate improvement in vitality.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change From Baseline in QoL at Week 52
outcomeMeasures.description: Change from baseline in QoL was assessed using the SF-36 QoL questionnaire at week 52. Scores could range from 0 to 100 with a high score indicating a better QoL. Positive change from baseline scores indicate improvement in QoL.

outcomeMeasures.title: Clinical Global Assessment of Efficacy
outcomeMeasures.description: Overall clinical efficacy was assessed by the Investigator using the following global ratings: very good, good, moderate, poor, or very poor, at weeks 4, 24, and 52.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Dose of Study Treatment
outcomeMeasures.description: Number of subjects with change in dose of study treatment was assessed at weeks 4, 24, and 52.

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Dose of Study Treatment During Titration Phase (First 4 Weeks of Study) and Overall Treatment Phase I (First 24 Weeks of Study)
outcomeMeasures.description: Number of subejcts with change in dose of study treatment was assessed and stratified by time on study, at least 4 weeks versus dropped out at highest dose before week 4, at weeks 4 and 24.

outcomeMeasures.title: Number of Drop-outs
outcomeMeasures.description: Number of drop-outs according to reasons for drop-out and due to inefficacy at maximal dosage was assessed at weeks 24 and 52.

outcomeMeasures.title: Number of Days With add-on Pain Medication
outcomeMeasures.description: Number of days with add-on pain medication during the first 24 weeks of the study was assessed at week 24.

outcomeMeasures.title: Amount of add-on Pain Medication
outcomeMeasures.description: Total amount of add-on pain medication (paracetamol) for the first 24 weeks was assessed at week 24.

outcomeMeasures.title: Mode and Convenience of Drug Intake.
outcomeMeasures.description: Subjects filled out a questionnaire based on the mode and convenience of drug intake and could rate their responses as very convenient, convenient, neither convenient or inconvenient, inconvenient, and very inconvenient.

outcomeMeasures.title: Resource Utilization of Pain Management
outcomeMeasures.description: Resource utilization was defined as the number of additional visits including additional telephone visits during the treatment period. This was assessed at week 24.

outcomeMeasures.title: Equi-analgesic Dosage of OROS Hydromorphone Once-daily and SR Oxycodone Twice-daily (PP Population)
outcomeMeasures.description: If non-inferiority of OROS hydromorphone was established, the daily dose of OROS hydromorphone and SR oxycodone that induced the same pain control was to be calculated (average dose used at week 24). Relative equi-analgesic dose was defined as mean dose/allowed maximum dose\*100. Allowed maximum doses were 32mg OROS hydromorphone and 80mg SR oxycodone respectively.

outcomeMeasures.title: Equi-analgesic Dosage of OROS Hydromorphone Once-daily and SR Oxycodone Twice-daily (ITT Population)
outcomeMeasures.description: If non-inferiority of OROS hydromorphone was established, the daily dose of OROS hydromorphone and SR oxycodone that induced the same pain control was to be calculated (average dose used at week 24). Relative equi-analgesic dose was defined as mean dose/allowed maximum dose\*100. Allowed maximum doses were 32mg OROS hydromorphone and 80mg SR oxycodone respectively.

outcomeMeasures.title: Equi-analgesic Dose at Steady-state (PP Population)
outcomeMeasures.description: Dose of OROS hydromorphone and SR oxycodone that induced the same pain control at steady state, defined as the mean dose from week 4 to week 24.

outcomeMeasures.title: Equi-analgesic Dose at Steady State (ITT Population)
outcomeMeasures.description: Dose of OROS hydromorphone and SR oxycodone that induced the same pain control at steady state, defined as the mean dose from week 4 to week 24.
